Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Multiscale Interaction Potentials for Cellulose
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The Division of Materials Research and the Chemistry Division contribute funds to this award. This SusChEM project involves computational research on the conversion of cellulosic biomass to biofuel as a sustainable energy source and a sustainable feedstock for new materials. Biofuel derived from perennial plants, such as grass, is most desirable since these plants grow on marginal land and can be harvested repeatedly. One major roadblock for economical utilization of plant biomass is the resistance of cellulosic fibrils to pretreatment to facilitate their conversion to usable fuels. Many questions regarding the detailed structures of fibrils and their interactions with water, other chemical solvents, and enzymes are poorly understood. The team will use high quality quantum mechanical computer simulations to develop accurate computational models to describe these interactions, with the ultimate goal of improving the efficiency of biomass conversion and for applications for the discovery and modeling of cellulose-based materials.

The research team will engage undergraduate and graduate students in sustainability research which aims to find solutions to enable the balance of carbon emission with carbon sequestration. Students will have the opportunity to visit Oak Ridge National Laboratory and experience research in a government laboratory. The team will develop a self-contained computational chemistry USB memory stick with packages to perform electronic structure and other modeling. The computer programs contained will include many that can be used without a detailed knowledge of molecular quantum mechanics. The team will disseminate the USB memory stick to regional colleges and help the faculty to incorporate modeling in their classrooms. The PI will also develop modeling modules and tutorials to teach concepts in physical and organic chemistry curricula.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The Division of Materials Research and the Chemistry Division contribute funds to this award. Through this SusChEM project, the research team will develop a multiscale model for cellulose fibrils and investigate fundamental properties of fibrils and fiber bundles with application to sustainable energy and the discovery of sustainable cellulose-based materials.

The research team will develop an accurate potential for cellulose by fitting to accurate electronic structure forces using the adaptive force matching method. Through an iterative procedure, adaptive force matching provides both high quality reference forces and representative training sets for fitting. This allows accurate force fields to be developed without using very complex energy expressions. As a consequence, larger structures can be modeled efficiently.

Once the adaptive force matching cellulose force field is available, an accurate coarse-grained potential will be developed using the multiscale coarse-graining approach. The coarse-grained potential will allow long cellulose fibrils and fibril bundles to be modeled.
The cellulose potential will be developed with only electronic structure information as input. The model will be validated to reproduce experimental properties, such as lattice constants and rotamer distributions. The validated all-atom and coarse-grained potentials will be used to address fundamental problems of cellulosic fibrils, including the number of chains in a fibril, the tendency for twisting, rotamer conformations at the interface, free energy of polymorph transformations, and the persistence length of the fibril.
The accurate multiscale potentials to be developed will enable reliable modeling of hydrated cellulosic fibrils, and further research in modeling cellulosic biomass and cellulose-based materials. The cellulose force field will be a stepping stone for the developments of additional models that involve alternative solvents, such as ionic liquids, and enzymes.

Successful development of an accurate cellulose potential will represent a major advance of adaptive force matching. The development of adaptive force matching into a reliable protocol for mapping an expensive electronic structure potential to a simple molecular mechanics force field will have broad impact for material research in general.

This award also supports educational activities to integrate computational modeling into Chemistry education. A self-contained computational chemistry USB memory stick will be developed to facilitate computer modeling by undergraduate students and the use of computer modeling in classrooms. No installation or licensing is needed, allowing the user to focus on the problem instead of computational details. The PI will disseminate the USB memory stick to regional colleges and help the faculty incorporate modeling in their classrooms. The PI will also develop modeling modules and tutorials to teach important concepts in physical and organic chemistry. The PIs will engage undergraduate and graduate students in carbon neutral sustainability research and provide them with the opportunity to visit Oak Ridge National Laboratory and experience research in a national laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the proposed research, DMR1609650, is to develop force fields for cellulose and study the physical chemistry of cellulose recalcitrance. A force field is the simplified energy expression and the associated parameters to model molecular interactions. Force field development is a big challenge. Most existing approaches for force field development are empirical in nature, especially for the development of pair-wise additive potentials. A systematic theoretical framework for force field development is lacking.

A fundamental goal of the proposed research is to better understand challenges in force-field development and establish theoretical framework for force field development using carbohydrates as a testing ground. The broader impacts include engaging undergraduate and graduate students with related research, increasing the outreach of minority students,  and developing an integrated modeling environment for undergraduate education.

With the DMR1609650 support, the team led by the PI published a total of 16 papers in peer reviewed journals detailing different discoveries related to the research theme. Two additional publications are in various stages of developments.

The systematic method we are developing for force field development is called adaptive force matching (AFM). Important problems addressed with the grant support includes a way to assign the most appropriate partial charges in a force field, the importance of basis set super-position error, and the proper correlation of core electrons in computing the reference gradient information in force field development. Exploring the circumstance, under which force field parameters developed for one model can be used in a different model, and modeling of important quantum nuclear effects by a force field without explicit usage of path-integral based methods are also studied.   

The code for AFM and associated toolkit to interface our force-matching code with other computational packages have been developed and released.

The senior personnel Pulay has created a divide-and-conquer based MP2 implementation for fast gradient calculations. This work is important in polysaccharide force field developments since DFT is known to provide a rather poor description of hydrogen bonds. The possibility of using MP2 reference forces significantly increases the quality of the polysaccharide potential.

With existing CHARMM force fields for cellulose, Cheng lab has performed several large sets of molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to systematically study how organosolvents (mainly THF, but also include acetone, ethanol, and GVL) facilitate the physical deconstruction of a cellulose fibril in the context of a simplified biomass model consisting of cellulose, xylan and lignin. These simulations highlight the importance of an accurate description of cellulose-cellulose interaction and its interaction with environmental components in the study of cellulose degradation and recalcitrance.

Broader Impact: Force fields for 20 different salts and models for CO2, graphene-water have been released on the group website for use by other researchers worldwide. The CReate Your Own Force Field (CRYOFF) code has been released with a manual and tutorial to enable development of custom force fields for other systems. A set of tools that automate AFM workflow has been developed and released on the group website.

Opportunities have been provided for three graduate students and two postdocs including a female student. Two undergraduates also got opportunity learning related simulations. One of the graduate students received his Ph. D during the funding period. One of the postdoctoral fellows recently started in a new position at Brandeis University.

A computational modeling USB stick, complete with an efficient GUI and all standard quantum chemistry models, including CCSD(T), has been developed inhouse and used at the 2016 INBRE conference. A Virtual Machine (VM) based version was also developed and showcased at the 2018 INBRE conference.

We released the VM based modeling environment, based on the PQS suite, on the group website to allow non-experts to learn computational modeling without installing a large number of programs. A tutorial was also developed and released with the VM.  The VM version was preferred over the USB stick based version due to its better compatibility and easiness of deployment.

The PI help started a monthly graduate student METhODS meeting. METhODS stands for Modeling, Experiments, THeory, and Operations for Doctoral Students. Its mission is to advance human resource development for STEM graduate students across campus.
